    <div class="published" id="main">
     <div class="ajax-delay-load" id="storyWrapper">
      <div class="article collapsable-panel" data-story_id="744905" id="article-1">
       <div class="meta share-expanded">
        <div class="clearfix" id="group_info">
         <div class="image" style="float: left; border: 1px solid #cccccc; margin-right: 20px">

          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="heading">
          <span class="name">
           Karmafish
          </span>
          <span class="follow">

        <p class="date">
         Sat Jun 20, 2009 at 11:18 AM PDT
        </p>
        <h2>
         <a href="/story/2009/06/20/744905/-I-Was-Wrong-about-Anti-Zionists" id="titleHref">
          I Was Wrong about Anti-Zionists
         </a>
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
         </span>
        </h2>
        <p class="author">
         <span>
          by
         </span>
         <a href="/user/Karmafish">
          Karmafish
         </a>
         <a alt="Follow this author" class="ajax type-user do-hotlist do-updateContent size-tiny off altTooltip" href="#?friend_id=55790&amp;is_stream=1">
          Follow
         </a>
        </p>
        <ul class="front-page-share clearfix">
         <li style="margin-left: 0px">
          <div class="fb-share-button" data-href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2009/06/20/744905/-I-Was-Wrong-about-Anti-Zionists" data-layout="button_count">
          </div>
         </li>
         <li>
          <a class="twitter-share-button" data-count="horizontal" data-related="markos" data-text="I Was Wrong about Anti-Zionists" data-url="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2009/06/20/744905/-I-Was-Wrong-about-Anti-Zionists" data-via="dailykos" href="https://twitter.com/share">
           Tweet
          </a>
         </li>
         <li>
          <a class="comments comment_count_with_new" data-comment_count="433" data-story_id="744905" href="/story/2009/06/20/744905/-I-Was-Wrong-about-Anti-Zionists#comments">
           433 Comments
          </a>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </div>
       <div class="article-body">
        <div id="intro">
         <p>
          For a long time, now, I have been suggesting that left anti-Zionism often serves as a shroud for anti-Semitism and that the constant vilification and demonization of Israel is anti-Semitic when the people doing that vilifying ignore Darfur and Congo and Sri Lanka and the Chinese in Tibet.
         </p>
         <p>
          I must admit that I was wrong and I hereby issue an apology.
         </p>
         <p>
          I live in San Francisco and I love my town. Some months ago there was
          <a href="http://zombietime.com/gaza_war_protest/">
           a protest against Israels Gaza incursion
          </a>
          and here are a few photos demonstrating just how wrong I was.
         </p>
         <p>
          Lets get directly to the matter, shall we?
         </p>
         <p>
          This nice lady carried a sign reading, "Jews are terroist!" I am not certain what a "terroist" is, but criticism of Israel is not, I repeat, NOT anti-Semitism. By the way, aren't her daughters as cute as little anti-Zionist buttons?
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=anti_jewish_poster-300x285.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/anti_jewish_poster-300x285.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
        </div>
        <p class="divider-doodle">
        </p>
        <div class="article-body" id="body">
         <p>
          Now, given the overly extreme sensitivities of
          <del>
           Jews
          </del>
          "Zionists" you would think that someone carrying such a sign would be asked to leave or put it away. Did that happen? Not exactly.
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=antisemitism.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/antisemitism.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          Smile pretty for the camera!
         </p>
         <p>
          Some of the pro-Israel, "Zionist" crowd has suggested that the left is often supportive of Hamas despite their Jew Killing agenda as laid out in
          <a href="http://www.acpr.org.il/resources/hamascharter.html">
           their charter,
          </a>
          which reads, in part:
         </p>
         <blockquote>
          <p>
           The time will not come until Muslims will fight the Jews (and kill them); until the Jews hide behind rocks and trees, which will cry: O Muslim! there is a Jew hiding behind me, come on and kill him!
          </p>
         </blockquote>
         <p>
          But this is clearly false. No one on the left actually supports Hamas:
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=Hamas-1.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/Hamas-1.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          No one on the left would be caught dead supporting a blood-thirsty, gay-hating, woman-oppressing, Jew-killing, theocratic organization like Hamas. Its just that Hamas is misunderstood. They cant help themselves. Besides, its all Israels fault.
         </p>
         <p>
          And since it is all Israels fault, you really cannot blame people for wanting to kill "Zionists."
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=Zionazi.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/Zionazi.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          Or ZioNazis, anyway. This fine gentleman of the left has nothing against Jews, just evil ZioNazis who are legitimate military targets. Kill the ZioNazis! Of course, since the vast majority of Jewish people happen to favor the existence of the Jewish state (for some dumb reason) this would make them Zionists and, thus, Nazis. And we all know what to do with Nazis. Just what this gentleman suggests, eh? But no reasonable person could possibly consider such a stance, the killing of "Zionists," to be anti-Semitic. This is merely criticism of Israel and again, criticism of Israel is NOT anti-Semitic and anyone who suggests otherwise is a GIYUS Hasbara troll trying to shut down the discussion.
         </p>
         <p>
          Here is this mans criticism of Israel:
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=Smash.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/Smash.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          Smash the Jewish state? Thats a good question. Should Israel, or should Israel not, be destroyed? There is something like 13 million Jews in the world, a whopping .2% of the world population, and nearly 40% of them live in Israel. But the question of whether or not to wipe them out is not anti-Jewish. It is a merely a question that people of good will can disagree upon.
         </p>
         <p>
          Now, the European Union has declared that equating Israel with Nazi Germany is anti-Semitic, but given Europes famous love for the Jewish people, it is not surprising that they would suggest this. The problem is that there is just too much good will toward Jews in Europe and they are far, far too overprotective of their Jewish citizenry. Just because Jewish schools and synagogues have to be guarded by the police from possible attack means nothing. And just because anti-Jewish violence is rising there is no cause for concern. National Socialism, of course, is generally considered the worst, the most vicious, political movement in world history and they had to be destroyed. But comparing Israel to Nazi Germany is not anti-Semitic. It is, again, merely criticism of Israel. There is nothing wrong with criticizing Israel, just as there is nothing wrong with criticizing any other country. And just because Israel is like Nazi Germany, and Nazi Germany had to be destroyed, Jewish people should not get so head-up about this mild criticism.
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=fascist.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/fascist.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=NaziIsrael.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/NaziIsrael.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          And just because Zionism, the movement for Jewish self-determination and self-defense, is just like Nazism is also no reason for Jews to object to such a characterization.
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=Nazism.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/Nazism.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          Of course, some people consider Jews to actually be worse than Nazis. The picture below shows a Star of David, the symbol of the Jewish people, with a "greater than" symbol pointing to a Nazi Swastika. I understand that a tiny percentage of blood-thirsty Jewish neo-cons would object to such a characterization, but the neo-cons gave us the Iraq war and thus should not be listened to. The suggestion that Jewish people are actually worse than Nazis is nothing but criticism of Israel. It is not meant to offend Jews and it certainly should not be taken to mean that Jews are evil and must be gotten rid of.
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=NeverAgain.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/NeverAgain.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          Never again? It's a question, really. Probably never again. Perhaps.
         </p>
         <p>
          Nonetheless, as I am sure you will all agree, the Intifada needs to be globablized.
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=intifada.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/intifada.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          All this person is suggesting is that people of good will around the globe must take to the streets in violent confrontation with "Zionists" wherever they might be found. Just because the vast majority of Jews support the Jewish state and are, thus, "Zionists" doesnt mean that they should object to a global Intifada.
         </p>
         <p>
          In fact, Jewish people, as a matter of social justice, should join with their anti-Zionist brothers and sisters calling for violent reprisals against... "Zionists"!
         </p>
         <p>
          Some of you, btw, may have heard of a recent police shooting of an unarmed man in Oakland in the Oakland City BART station. One liberal anti-Zionist protester, reasonably enough, blames this on the Jews.
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=Oakland.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/Oakland.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          The suggestion, of course, is that Israels recent criminal Zionist genocidal massacre in Gaza is directly connected to that shooting. But it cannot be said enough that criticism of Israel is not anti-Semitic.
         </p>
         <p>
          Criticism of Israel is not anti-Semitic.
         </p>
         <p>
          Criticism of Israel is not anti-Semitic.
         </p>
         <p>
          And there was Cindy.
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="http://s67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/?action=view&amp;current=Cindy.jpg" target="_blank">
           <img alt="Photobucket" border="" src="http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h303/Karmafish/Cindy.jpg"/>
          </a>
         </p>
         <p>
          What a shame.
         </p>
         <p>
          And, again, I apologize.
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
       <h4>
        Originally posted to
        <a href="/blog/Karmafish/">
         Karmafish
        </a>
        on Sat Jun 20, 2009 at 11:18 AM PDT.
       </h4>
       <div class="tags">

      </div>

      </div>

        <input name="story_id" type="hidden" value="744905"/>
        <style>
         #popup-story_setTags div.content-bar p { font-size: 13px; text-align: left; }
	#popup-story_setTags div.content-bar a			{ color: #E5721E }

        <br/>
        <div>
         <p>
          Add keywords that describe this diary.
		Separate multiple keywords with commas.
          <br/>
          <a href="/special/tag_tips" target="_blank">
           Tagging tips
          </a>
          -
          <a href="/search?search_tags=1" target="_blank">
           Search For Tags
          </a>
          -
          <a href="http://www.dkosopedia.com/wiki/Tag:Tagfinder" target="_blank">
           Browse For Tags
          </a>
         </p>
         <div class="pageTip hasTooltip" style="margin-top:3px">
          ?
         </div>
         <div class="tooltipContents qtip-style-dk4_large qtip-pos-br">
          <p>
           <b>
            More Tagging tips:
           </b>
          </p>
          <p>
           A tag is a way to search for this diary. If someone is searching for "Barack Obama," is this a diary they'd be trying to find?
          </p>
          <p>
           Use a person's full name, without any title. Senator Obama may become President Obama, and Michelle Obama might run for office.
          </p>
          <p>
           If your diary covers an election or elected official, use election tags, which are generally the state abbreviation followed by the office. 
		CA-01 is the first district House seat. CA-Sen covers both senate races. NY-GOV covers the New York governor's race.
          </p>
          <p>
           Tags do not compound: that is, "education reform" is a completely different tag from "education". A tag like "reform" alone is probably not meaningful.
          </p>
         </div>
         <!-- &lt;h4 id="p_tagErrorMessage"&gt;You must enter at least one Tag for this Diary Entry:&lt;/h4&gt; -->
         <p>
          <input id="p_tagInput" name="tag_draft" size="70" type="text" value=""/>
          <!-- &lt;input id="tagSubmit" type="submit" name="submit" value="Submit" /&gt; -->
         </p>
         <p style="font-style:italic">
          Consider if one or more of these tags fits your diary:
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Civil Rights');return false;">
           Civil Rights
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Community');return false;">
           Community
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Congress');return false;">
           Congress
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Culture');return false;">
           Culture
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Economy');return false;">
           Economy
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Education');return false;">
           Education
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Elections');return false;">
           Elections
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Energy');return false;">
           Energy
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Environment');return false;">
           Environment
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Health Care');return false;">
           Health Care
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('International');return false;">
           International
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Labor');return false;">
           Labor
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Law');return false;">
           Law
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Media');return false;">
           Media
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Meta');return false;">
           Meta
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('National Security');return false;">
           National Security
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Science');return false;">
           Science
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Transportation');return false;">
           Transportation
          </a>
          , or
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('White House');return false;">
           White House
          </a>
          .
	If your diary is specific to a state, consider adding the state 
	(
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('California');return false;">
           California
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Texas');return false;">
           Texas
          </a>
          , etc).
	Keep in mind, though, that there are many wonderful and important diaries
	that don't fit in any of these tags. Don't worry if yours doesn't.
         </p>

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             On the rare occassions when I actual publish a diary, I very much prefer to write my own tip-jar, but noooooooooo.
            </p>
            <p>
             Fine.
            </p>
            <p>
             I can live with it.
            </p>
            <p>
             And, again, my sincerest apologies for being overly concerned about the well-being of Jewish people.
            </p>

               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 A bit Canned, ain't it?
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/744905/29406226#c338?mode=alone;showrate=1#c338">
                  8+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:46176">
                   capelza
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:72289">
                   Lefty Coaster
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:98698">
                   heathlander
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:160547">

                  </a>

                  <a href="/user/uid:162558">
                   sortalikenathan
                  </a>

                  <a href="/user/uid:192719">

                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:199419">
                   Fire bad tree pretty
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:202377">
                   palestinian professor
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 I mean, January or so and now it's June.
                </p>
                <p>
                 At that time, Palestinians were dying in Gaza and no end in sight. Just like Iranians here can't sleep at night now, Arabs couldn't sleep back then; I know. It was even hard for me to sleep some nights.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Against this background, some people certainly went out of line during these protests. In Seattle I personally confronted such people face-to-face and on email. There is always the nutcase (or the super-heated person) to put up an unacceptable sign.
                </p>
                <p>
                 When I floated the issue, it became quite clear that the vast majority of people in the demonstrations agreed with me, including all the organizers. Yet, when emotions are as heated, it is hard to control everyone. As everyone knows.
                </p>
                <p>
                 What you are doing now, Karmafish, is not only deliberate flame, but also a guilt-by-association to anyone who attack Israeli policies.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Answering in the same coin, I could say that you and all who uprated you, would have participated in the staging of
                 <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-EsVsHvKRac&amp;eurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.haaretz.co.il%2Fhasite%2Fspages%2F1093913.html&amp;feature=player_embedded">
                  this.
                 </a>
                </p>
                <p>
                 <object height="344" width="425">
                  <param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/-EsVsHvKRac&amp;hl=en&amp;fs=1">
                  </param>
                  <param name="allowFullScreen" value="true">
                  </param>
                  <param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always">
                  </param>
                  <embed allowfullscreen="true" allowscriptaccess="always" height="344" src="http://www.youtube.com/v/-EsVsHvKRac&amp;hl=en&amp;fs=1" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="425">
                  </embed>
                 </object>
                </p>
                <p>
                 An interesting time you and your pals find to go on the offense. Just as Israel is pretty much at its ugliest. Strange how the mind works.
                </p>
               </div>
               <div class="cf">
                <p class="sig">
                 <a href="http://www.yeshgvul.org" rel="nofollow">

                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    Have just done some investigating and found an article at
                    <a href="http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1094019.html">
                     Haaretz
                    </a>
                    (h/t Angry Arab) with the same video. Their translation is as follows:
                   </p>
                   <blockquote>
                    <p>
                     In one clip uploaded to the video sharing website an Arab youth is shown in arid terrain, slapping himself, while a voice is heard instructing him to say "I love you, Border Police," and "I will f**k you, Palestine," in Arabic. The victim is forced to respond to everything he is ordered to do, to the raucous laughter of the cameraman and his friends, all Border Policemen.
                    </p>
                   </blockquote>
                   <p>
                    I didn't understand the word for border police (maybe because it was Hebrew and not Arabic?) which was why it was hard for me to get the context.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    This behavior on the part of the Border Police is outrageous and intolerable. When added to the other usual humiliations and brutalities of the occupation, the effects are horrendous.
                   </p>
                  </div>

                   <p class="sig">

                   <p class="cb">
                    by
                    <a href="/user/uid:199419">

                 <div class="ct">
                  <p>
                   Soldier: say I love the border police (army)
                   <br/>
                   Child: I love you border police
                   <br/>
                   Soldier: again I love the border police
                   <br/>
                   Child: I love you border police
                   <br/>
                   Soldier: say Allah, oh Allah, oh uncle
                   <br/>
                   Child: Allah oh uncle
                   <br/>
                   Other soldier: one humos one fool I love mishmar gvool
                   <br/>
                   (the Army)
                   <br/>
                   Child: one humos one fool I love mishmar gvool
                   <br/>
                   Soldier: say I fuck Palestine
                   <br/>
                   Child: I fuck Palestine.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Here is an article about the video
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <a href="http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1094019.html">
                    http://haaretz.com/...
                   </a>
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   Personally, I hope that these army folk die of the flue. Racism will fall and so will the ideology that feeds it.
                  </p>
                 </div>

                  <p class="sig">

                 <div class="cx" id="cx29407542">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Only to inform, not to nitpick.
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/744905/29407542#c377?mode=alone;showrate=1#c377">
                     1+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="crs">
                   <dl>
                    <dt>
                     Recommended by:
                    </dt>
                    <dd>
                     <a href="/user/uid:201740">
                      Bidet
                     </a>
                    </dd>
                   </dl>
                  </div>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    Your sentence:
                    <br/>
                    "Personally, I hope that these army folk die of the flue."
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Should be "flu" as in "influenza", whereas a "flue" is a part of a fireplace which opens it to the chimney.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Again, mentioned only to inform/educate, not to nitpick yer typing/spelling. For all I know, it was a typo, but I wanted to help you be clear in the future.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Celtic Merlin
                    <br/>
                    Carlinist
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">

                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  For the life of me
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/744905/29411591#c403?mode=alone;showrate=1#c403">
                   0+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  I do not understand why this diary should be the least bit controversial.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  All I am saying, clearly, is that the Israel = Nazi Germany analogy creates hatred toward Jews, more generally.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  It should be opposed, whatever anyone's views of I-P.
                 </p>
                </div>

                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">

                   </span>

                     </a>
                     (here's a link to the

                     </a>

                     <a href="http://www.notes.co.il/idanl/57658.asp">

                     </a>

                    </p>
                    <p>
                     The story also exposes, that this phenomenon has been known for a while by IDF/police high officers, who turned a blind eye.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Thank heavens, Israel has no extermination plans for Palestinians at the moment.
                     <strong>
                      But Nazism unfortunately is part of human history and legacy. Anyone can become a Nazi.
                     </strong>
                     It is not a German genetic predisposition (as some idiot American-Jewish "scholar" argued in his junk Ph.D. thesis), and Jews are not immune from it.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Ruling out any Israel and Nazism analogy - while at the same time hurling the analogy at any Arab/Muslim foe of Israel - is meaningless crap.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Rather than nit-pick at anyone criticizing Israel, I think you'll serve Israel better
                     <strong>
                      by looking very carefully at where it's going, and writing about how it can save itself.
                     </strong>
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     Your diary has done neither.

                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       There is certainly extermination-type "death to the Arabs" talk on the Israeli street. Lots of it. Just like there is this type of talk in the Palestinian street.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Like there is in many countries with this type of intense conflict and incitement. Sadly enough, humans do have the genocidal instinct. Even the Bible prescribes genocide to some people, and brings examples of genocides happening.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       The shit hits the fan, when power is seized by (or legally given to, doesn't matter) people who vow to be "honest" to the public, and carry out their policies on the same level of the street talk.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       People like Mossulini or Hitler or Pol Pot.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       I am afraid that Avigdor Yvet Lieberman is getting frightfully close to this group. And he is Israel's foreign minister now.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       <strong>
                        I plan to watch him closely.
                       </strong>
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       You can plan to shut people up meanwhile.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       As to your eye-rolling
                      </p>
                      <blockquote>
                       <p>
                        I have never done so.
                       </p>
                      </blockquote>
                      <p>
                       (never compared foes of Israel to Nazis):
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Well, maybe you personally didn't but everyone and their sister have done so. Comparing Hamas to Nazis (what's all the "Islamo-fascism" crap about? Not every ideology we don't like is a form of fascism). And so on.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Are you going out of your way to police these analogies? Or is this a "beat-on-one-side-only" tool you are using here? As I said at this thread's start, I did confront Arab demonstrators when I thought they used the analogy in a bad way.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Anyway, if your sole mission in life is to control who says "Nazi" when, and even if you are honest about how you try to do it - well, good luck with that.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       It is more useful to make sure the discussion is intelligent and respectful.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       And again, it is even more useful to focus on where Israel-Palestine is now, where it's heading and how we can steer it to a good direction.
                       <strong>
                        If someone raises a Nazi analogy along the way: well, we can deal with each one when it comes, as grown-ups.
                       </strong>

                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      I appreciate your point about hypocrisy. However, how does playing into the whole nazi-baiting meme accomplish anything other than reinforcing the behavior you object to?
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Moreover, It's not even clear what you mean by nazi. One of the primary tenets of actual, historical nazism was its racial definition. It's a simple matter of fact that not just "anyone" could, or can, become a nazi. Further, you specifically state that whatever its defects, the Israeli government does not have an exterminationist policy towards the Palestinians. Yet just such an agenda is also a fundamental characteristic of nazism.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Given such factual inaccuracies, again I have to ask, what possible constructive purpose can articulating this meme serve?
                     </p>

                    <div class="cx" id="cx29421886">
                     <h5>
                      <a class="de">
                      </a>
                      <span class="cu">
                       Assaf is speaking
                      </span>
                      <span class="crd ntb">
                       (
                       <a href="/comments/744905/29421886#c423?mode=alone;showrate=1#c423">

                        <a href="/user/uid:107317">

                       </dd>
                      </dl>
                     </div>
                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       from an Israeli perspective as an Israeli who is outraged by the behavior of these soldiers toward this Palestinian child in the video.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Unlike the US, Israel commemorates the Nazi Holocaust every year. School children in Israel, including myself, are taught about how the Nazi soldiers humiliated Jews and took pictures of themselves doing so. We are shown the picture. The stories are told to us in intimate details.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       What do you think comes to our minds when we see these Israeli army thugs forcing this child to slap himself and say "I fuck Palestine"?
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Of course, it is Nazi imagery that comes to our mind without hesitation because living in Israel the memories of the Holocaust and the behavior of the Nazi soldiers are alive in people's minds, educationally, politically, and culturally.
                      </p>
                      <p>

                    <li id="c428">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx29431963">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        Prof
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/744905/29431963#c428?mode=alone;showrate=1#c428">
                         0+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        I understand what you're saying but it's a psychological reality outside of I/P as well. The historical fact of nazism established a standard of oppression and political malevolence in the European context that has cast a shadow over all political analysis since WWII. This was apparent in cold war propaganda and it has remained a key part of apologetics for US military adventures from that time to the present (Saddam=Hitler, Iran=Nazi Germany, ad nauseum)
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        I imagine you would agree that such comparisons are factually challenged.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        As you yourself indicate, the appeal of nazi comparisons is primarily emotional rather than analytical. The mental reflex that you describe is identical to that which I experience in the face of any example of political oppression and brutality. Particularly so since I was born in the deep south of the US when racial Apartheid was the law of the land.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Needless to say, this system had many features in common with nazism. Nevertheless, to have equated the two systems would have been both factually inaccurate and an abuse of history. Moreover, it would have obscured rather than enlightened since it leads away from the discussion of particular, present evils into a sterile debate over whether such evils rise to the level of the atrocities committed by the nazis. Actual human suffering becomes secondary to what is essentially an academic question. Anyone who isn't moved by the actual, material plight of the Palestinians is hardly likely to experience a moral awakening based on being compared to a nazi.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The point is that brutishness is brutishness regardless of political coloration. What matters is that we put an end to it. Whatever the emotional justification for Assaf's comparison, can you argue that it forwards this goal?
                       </p>
                       <p>
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                       </p>
                       <p class="cb">
                        by
                        <a href="/user/uid:66748">
                         WB Reeves
                        </a>
                        on
                        <a href="/comments/744905/29431963#c428">
                         Mon Jun 22, 2009 at 01:32:02 PM PDT
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cl">
                        [
                        <a href="#c423">
                         Parent
                        </a>
                        ]
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                   </ul>
                   <li id="c427">
                    <div class="cx" id="cx29429198">
                     <h5>
                      <a class="de">
                      </a>
                      <span class="cu">
                       To add to Palestinian Prof's excellent response
                      </span>
                      <span class="crd ntb">
                       (
                       <a href="/comments/744905/29429198#c427?mode=alone;showrate=1#c427">
                        0+ / 0-
                       </a>
                       )
                      </span>
                     </h5>
                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       which I wholly endorse (which, in a nutshell, says that Nazism/Holocaust is an intimate part of my psyche and historical-reference bank as an Israeli Jew, so no surprise we use it on both right and left):
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       About the usefulness of an analogy, that's perhaps the strongest argument against using it. It stirs up shit, and can distract from the issue. But since the right-wing side uses it night and day anyway, this horse is probably out of the stable. Maybe it's better to demonstrate that this sword has two edges, not only one.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       And unfortunately, there is a lot to draw analogies upon nowadays. Really, unfortunately. I am not happy to make this point. Believe me.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Again, as he pointed out I am probably more aware of the history of Nazism's rise and regime than most Kossacks here.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Extermination became the dominant policy on the ground only from summer 1941 onwards.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Before WWII, the official policy was "transfer". Kick the Jews (and others) out, let other countries deal with them.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Need I introduce to you the transferist element of Israeli politics? btw, current polls show a solid majority of Israeli Jews support some form of transfer. So even though a minority of Israel's leaders now espouse it, they may have an incentive to move more toward this direction.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       <strong>
                        Transfer as a preconceived "solution to demographic/cultural problems", is a Nazi idea.
                       </strong>
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       That's how I see it, based on history. Take it or leave it.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Then once WWII started and until mid-1941, Jews (and others) were herded into small areas, their movements restricted to near-zero, their livelihood controlled and limited, and their food supplies (and other supplies) constricted. Why? Officially, they were considered a "security risk" to everyone else.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Again,
                       <strong>
                        singling out a whole section of the population - men, women and children - and throwing them out of society to "fend for themselves" under impossible conditions, so that the rest of us will be "safer" - doing this in a modern setting is a characteristically Nazi innovation.
                       </strong>
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       In fact, the international conventions for human rights were formulated largely to prevent this from happening again; because in a way, what the Nazis did to the Jews in Occupied Poland was "not even illegal" at the time.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Need I really say more?
                      </p>
                     </div>

                      <p class="sig">
                       <a href="http://www.yeshgvul.org" rel="nofollow">

                   <ul class="cm i1" id="k29429198">
                    <li id="c429">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx29432518">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        Assaf
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/744905/29432518#c429?mode=alone;showrate=1#c429">
                         1+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="crs">
                       <dl>
                        <dt>
                         Recommended by:
                        </dt>
                        <dd>
                         <a href="/user/uid:107317">
                          Assaf
                         </a>
                        </dd>
                       </dl>
                      </div>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        The first suggestion that poison gas be used to eliminate Jews appeared in the pages of the first edition of Hitler's Mein Kampf. The Wanssee conference, to which you refer, was an meeting that worked out the administrative framework for the "final solution". That this "solution" was simply the realization of the nazi party's long established program we know from no less an authority than Heinrich Himmler.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Population transfer is not unique to nazism. Neither did it originate with them. It goes back to antiquity where it was practiced by both the Assyrians and the Babylonians.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Nor can it be argued that such transfers are unique to the nazis in the modern era. Such policy was applied by the US government against the indigenous tribes of North America well before the nazis and was, in fact, cited by Hitler as both precedent and model for his own policies.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        As for the horse the horse being out of the barn, I find that a poor rationale for aiding in subsuming the legitimate claims of the Palestinians in the swamp of tit for tat nazi-baiting.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                       </p>
                       <p class="cb">
                        by
                        <a href="/user/uid:66748">
                         WB Reeves
                        </a>
                        on
                        <a href="/comments/744905/29432518#c429">
                         Mon Jun 22, 2009 at 02:01:48 PM PDT
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cl">
                        [
                        <a href="#c427">

                        </a>

                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <li id="c430">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx29436321">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        Look, you have a point
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/744905/29436321#c430?mode=alone;showrate=1#c430">
                         1+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="crs">
                       <dl>
                        <dt>
                         Recommended by:
                        </dt>
                        <dd>
                         <a href="/user/uid:66748">
                          WB Reeves
                         </a>
                        </dd>
                       </dl>
                      </div>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        This is not black and white.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        We shouldn't aid and abet the gratuitous use of Nazi analogies in any context. (e.g., Seinfeld's "soup Nazi", etc.)
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        But we also shouldn't aid and abet the feigned indignation whenever such an analogy is brought by someone in a context we find inconvenient. Nazism and Holocaust are a part of modern and Jewish history; Palestinians were in a large part made to pay the price of the Holocaust's aftermath. An absolute "Nazi gag order" on Arabs is not any better than a stupid "Israel=Nazis" sign.
                        <br/>
                        Both serve to derail and devolve the debate.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                      <div class="cf">
                       <p class="sig">
                        <a href="http://www.yeshgvul.org" rel="nofollow">
                         Yesh Gvul
                        </a>
                        ,
                        <a href="http://villagesgroup.wordpress.com/" rel="nofollow">
                         The Villages Group
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cb">
                        by
                        <a href="/user/uid:107317">
                         Assaf
                        </a>
                        on
                        <a href="/comments/744905/29436321#c430">
                         Mon Jun 22, 2009 at 05:08:29 PM PDT
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p class="cl">
                        [
                        <a href="#c429">
                         Parent
                        </a>
                        ]
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <li id="c432">
                     <div class="cx" id="cx29442691">
                      <h5>
                       <a class="de">
                       </a>
                       <span class="cu">
                        We are in agreement
                       </span>
                       <span class="crd ntb">
                        (
                        <a href="/comments/744905/29442691#c432?mode=alone;showrate=1#c432">
                         0+ / 0-
                        </a>
                        )
                       </span>
                      </h5>
                      <div class="ct">
                       <p>
                        I have no intention of giving a pass to anyone on this point. However, I recognize the anguish that fuels the resort to such rhetoric on both sides. Just as I recognize that there are those on both sides who cynically manipulate such anguish for their own political ends.
                       </p>
                      </div>

              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                themselves -- I'm been long aware of this strain on the left b/c I scan wingnut blogs, and it's good to expose it here, imo.
               </p>
               <p>
                I see you're accused of being inflammatory -- so what? I think it's b/c it makes some folks on the left 'uncomfortable' -- they prefer their anti-Semites caricatured as right wing nuts, but that's not the whole picture!
               </p>
               <p>
                There exists an alliance between the leftists/Marxists/anti-globalists, etc. types and the anti-Israel element.
               </p>
               <p>
                Impacting this emergence are 'Palestinian Solidarity Clubs' at the college/university level --of course, they're entitled to their views and their agenda, such as lobbying for de-investment in Israel, etc., but, again, it's good to shine some sunlight on them.
               </p>
               <p>
                We see you! :)
               </p>

               </p>
               <p>
                There is no excuse for the signs or the sentiment, but there was a comment you made downthread that would have been helpful, imo, as the diary commentary:
               </p>
               <blockquote>
                <p>
                 All I am saying is that there is (4+ / 0-)
                </p>
                <p>
                 an element on the left that dresses up their anti-Semitism in the language of anti-Zionism and, most gallingly, human rights.
                </p>
                <p>
                 We just need to be aware of it and say "NO" when it shows itself.
                </p>
                <p>
                 One way that it does so is in the Israel = Nazi Germany analogy.
                </p>
                <p>
                 This must be opposed.
                </p>
                <p>
                 I will of course vehemently oppose their anti-semitism
                </p>
                <p>
                 Thank you.
                </p>
                <p>
                 That is all I ask.
                </p>

             <ul class="cm i1" id="k29411930">
              <li id="c411">
               <div class="cx" id="cx29413785">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  That's fine Karma
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/744905/29413785#c411?mode=alone;showrate=1#c411">
                   2+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:180">
                    N in Seattle
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:201740">
                    Bidet
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  as long as we're talking about Nazi analogies but your formulation needs to make the distinction clear. Otherwise your argument could extend to any criticism of Israel. If the crux of your position is that "fair or not, people will associate Israel with Jews" what criticism of Israel could not be construed as anti-Semitic? Surely that isn't your intent?
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I oppose the Nazi analogy because it is both ahistorical and counter factual, serving only the purposes of provocation, vilification and incitement. This is true regardless of which side hurls the charge.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  To label one's opponent as a "nazi" is no small thing. It is not mere rhetoric. Labeling anyone or anything as "nazi" is identifying that person, organization or movement as a conscious agent of an aggressive, genocidal policy. It is naming your opponent as an active enemy of humanity as a whole, justifying the most extreme counter measures for their suppression. As a practical matter, the use of words rather than bullets against a nazi is simply a concession to civilized behavior. A concession not everyone is willing to make.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  This is why I personally will Hr anyone using such analogies in the context I/P debates, regardless of whether they are casting Israelis or Palestinians in the role of brownshirts.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I must say though, in my recollection, the deployment of the Nazi=Arab=Palestinian formulation goes back a good deal farther than the Israel=Nazi version.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                 </p>
                 <p class="cb">
                  by
                  <a href="/user/uid:66748">
                   WB Reeves
                  </a>
                  on
                  <a href="/comments/744905/29413785#c411">

                  </a>
                 </p>

                  <a href="#c407">

             <div class="ct">
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                <a href="http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1094242.html">
                 Israeli troops humiliate Palestinians - and put it on YouTube
                </a>
               </p>
               <p>
                For the "hero" of the clip, an unidentified young Arab, they were probably eternally long seconds and far from amusing. He was forced to slap himself and sing to the jubilant shouts of the photographer and his buddies - all of them members of Israel's Border Police.
               </p>
              </blockquote>
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                They see him obey in a subdued voice and with a frightened look, even as he goes on slapping himself. They hear the "director" laughing and the faceless voice shouting: "Again! Ana behibak Mishmar Hagvul."
               </p>
               <p>
                After a little more than 30 seconds, the voice says, "Say 'Wahad hummus wahad ful'" - and the Arab man obeys and then is told to complete the rhyme: "Ana behibak Mishmar Hagvul."
               </p>
               <p>
                After 40 seconds, the abusers appear to have had enough and the voice impatiently orders the victim: "Yallah, rukh, rukh, rukh" ("go"). The camera turns and for a fraction of a second a Border Police Jeep is visible.
               </p>
               <p>
                A few dozen viewers sent comments. "Hahahaha, it was great the way he excruciated himself." Another added: "That's how it should be!!!!! Stinking Arab."
               </p>
               <p>
                And a third pointed out, "He should have been shot!! Sons of bitches."
               </p>
              </blockquote>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               nor can we consume the world's resources without regard to effect. For the world has changed, and we must change with it. - Barack Obama

          <li id="c250">
           <div class="cx" id="cx29398979">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              asdf
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/744905/29398979#c250?mode=alone;showrate=1#c250">
               3+ / 0-
              </a>

            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:55019">
                jon the antizionist jew
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:72289">
                Lefty Coaster
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:107730">
                Terra Mystica
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <blockquote>
              <p>
               "What can the Israelis learn from your visit to Buchenwald and what should they be thinking about their treatment of Palestinians?"
              </p>
             </blockquote>
             <p>
              And what precisely is wrong with this comment? We should absolutely try to learn from the Holocaust, especially when it comes to the abuse of people's rights and the denial of their basic human dignity. To wonder what lessons the Holocaust might teach thoughtful Israelis with regards to Israel's treatment of Palestinians is perfectly legitimate, and in no way implies the kind of 'equivalence' CAMERA alleges.
             </p>
             <p>
              For a thoughtful discussion of (among other things) the moral lessons of the Holocaust, and how they might apply to Israel's treatment of the Palestinians, see this wonderful essay by
              <a href="http://www.normanfinkelstein.com/from-the-brilliant-and-wonderful-sara-roy/">
               Sara Roy
              </a>
              .
             </p>
            </div>

             <p class="sig">
              <i>
               <a href="http://heathlander.wordpress.com" rel="nofollow">

             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              (1) The diary exists solely to inflame people.
              <br/>
              (2) The arguments are false and rely on emotional content and conflation.
              <br/>
              (3) Karmafish refuses to engage any substantive responses to him/her (of which there are many in the diary), instead repeating the same Likudnik libel over and over again -- proving that the intent is propaganda and conflation.
              <br/>
              (4) Karmafish has several followers some of whom are doing the same thing.
             </p>
            </div>

             <p class="sig">

         <li id="c17">
          <div class="cx" id="cx29396284">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             I think it raises the issue
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/744905/29396284#c17?mode=alone;showrate=1#c17">
              7+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:16207">
               CN
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:55790">
               Karmafish
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:65438">
               oldskooldem
              </a>
              ,

              </a>

              <a href="/user/uid:82627">

              </a>
              ,

               notwisconsin
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:200478">
               Borat Sagdiyev
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             that the Democratic Party, the party for which most Jews vote, that has been historically tolerant, is facing a hijacking from the knee-jerk reaction of the anti-war movement to all things military, even when they are necessary, like Israel defending itself, or initial involvement of the US in Afghanistan. The crowd that blames US actions for all the world's problems, is now turning to blaming Israel, and seeing it as the sole cause for radical Islamic hatred against the West, when it is far from the truth. Most Democrats support Israel, as polls show, and most Jews support Israel and Democrats. No mainstream Democratic politician opposes Israel, and Cynthia McKinney is an example of a fringe politician, hence why she's no longer in the party.
            </p>
            <p>
             I'd also venture to argue that the idea that anything Bush did was evil, including being Israel's ally has fueled the anti-I wing of the left. Bush was horrible, and I think politically, he was the deadweight on Israel, as his Iraq war was why so many could turn to his other policies, like Israel, and say he was wrong.
            </p>
            <p>
             This diary raises the issue of the people we cannot allow to become mainstream of the Democratic Party. We cannot allow anti-Semites to speak for us. Yes, people should absolutely be able to criticize policies of Israel, but the behaviour shown in the pictures of this diary are hateful and disgusting. No one should appease these people or try to get their votes. No one should give them attention, except to ridicule them. We must not allow these people into the party. They've infested blogs, and the disease could spread like a virus.
            </p>
           </div>

                </strong>

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             that the moral universe has two choices:
            </p>
            <p>
             a) be wildly in favor of Israel's occupation
             <br/>
             b) be anti-semitic.
            </p>
            <p>
             This is the bullshit that has prevented a resolution, because it tries to undermines those, like me, who oppose vehemently China's occupation in Tibet, sudan's behavior in darfur, Morrocco's behavior in Western Sahara, the U.S. treatment of native americans to this day, the USSR's occupation of the Baltic States (back in the day, which I mention since this was my first issue in this area as my father was an Estonian refugee with no real right of return) and yes, Israel's brutal occupation of the terrirtories and it's repeated disprportionate attacks on its neighbors. Of the list of such state-level injustices going on, israel's actions are probably second only to darfur in terms of the moral repugnancy and violence and human suffering inflicted. Mugabe's reign of terror is the only close contender for the #2 spot I can think of.
            </p>
            <p>
             of course, I'm sure that's not at all motivated by a common humanitarian opposition to such brutalities,whether done in the name of nationalism or religion or both. Nope, since I'm a leftist, I must be ati-semitic, yep that's it.
            </p>
            <p>
             No, this is a thread frequently taken up by Israel apologists to try to undermine and silence their critics. It is the right-wing zionists equivalent of the myth that jews control everything. hence the HR.
            </p>
            <p>
             sadly, the result is that now when charges of anti-semitism are leveled against someone, the response is now a yawn, since everyone gets called an anti-semite these days by these folks. Which means that when it's truly deserved as in many of the examples above, it unfortunately carries much less weight. that's not right.
            </p>
           </div>

           <div class="crs">
            <dl>

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             but claims that Israel is something akin to Nazi Germany is far, far beyond that middle ground.
            </p>
            <p>
             This trend in anti-Zionist rhetoric must be stopped because it creates hatred, and thus violence, toward Jews.

                     </dl>
                    </div>
                    <div class="ct">
                     <p>
                      that a binational democratic secular state with a very large Jewish population and a Palestinian poulation split between Muslims, Chrisitians and secularists would become "another Islamic Republic"? These sort of lurid apocalyptic visions were widespread among white South Africans in the last days of apartheid and did not come to pass.
                     </p>

          <li id="c50">
           <div class="cx" id="cx29396604">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              OK I agree.
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/744905/29396604#c50?mode=alone;showrate=1#c50">
               3+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:46176">
                capelza
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:60388">
                neroden
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:89625">
                SpecialKinFlag
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              Claims that Israel is similar to the 3rd Reich are absurd and unnecessary. People who make such claims are fools, but not necessarily anti-semitic (although many of them could be).
             </p>
             <p>
              I had a Jewish professor in undergrad who was so anti-Israel he lost all perspective on the situation. He would make those Nazi comparisons, and frequently went to protests with inflammatory signs.
             </p>
             <p>
              However, he never extended his resentment of the state to resentment of its people. He was not an anti-semite, he was just anti-Israel to the point of ridiculousness.
             </p>
             <p>
              KarmaFish, you are by far one of the most reasonable pro-I commenters here that I have seen. May I ask that you edit this diary?
             </p>
             <p>
              Because at the moment it seems inflammatory, snide, and seems as though you are using the loonies to attack all anti-Zionists.
             </p>
             <p>
              If you remove the mocking and snide tone I will happily remove my HR and agree with this diary.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              We have weapons of mass destruction we have to address here at home. Poverty and homelessness are weapons of mass destruction. - Denny K
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:107152">
               Chicagoa
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/744905/29396604#c50">
               Sat Jun 20, 2009 at 11:52:40 AM PDT
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">
              [
              <a href="#c8">
               Parent
              </a>
              ]
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <li id="c107">
           <div class="cx" id="cx29397050">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              The trend
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/744905/29397050#c107?mode=alone;showrate=1#c107">
               7+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:46176">
                capelza
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:50405">
                corvo
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:55019">
                jon the antizionist jew
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:60388">
                neroden
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:80353">
                blueness
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:100966">
                Aunt Martha
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:201914">
                Conure
               </a>
              </dd>
             </dl>
            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              This is where your argument gets spurious. Everybody knows that there are anti-Semites who hide behind calling themselves anti-Zionists. But your purpose expressed quite explicitly here is to deliberately blur the distinction for the purpose of smearing anti-Zionists who are NOT anti-Semites. There is certainly a growing anti-Zionist tendency here and among progressives more broadly. But I see no evidence that the growth of that trend is fuelling greater anti-semitism. On the contrary what I see is more and more Jews and people who were previously scared away from opposing Israel by accusations of anti-Semitism coming forward and identifying as anti-Zionist in a manner that serves to
              <em>
               isolate
              </em>
              the anti-Semites. This, of course, is a much greater threat to Zionism than the haters and misguided souls featured in your diary. In a perverse sense the more that anti-Zionists conform to the image of anti-Semites the better from your point of view. You should think about that.
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              For Change You Can REALLY Believe IN:

            <li id="c141">
             <div class="cx" id="cx29397364">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Is it actually rising?
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/744905/29397364#c141?mode=alone;showrate=1#c141">
                 4+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:50405">
                  corvo
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:55019">
                  jon the antizionist jew
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:70454">
                  KenBee
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:191552">
                  thethinveil
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                I know that whenever it happens that Abe Foxman insists that it is rising. My sense is that while opposition to Israel certainly has increased, the overall frequency of incidents of anti-Semitic violence in the US is pretty much what it has been for decades, rising and falling modestly from year to year. I did a lot of anti-Nazi organizing in the 80s and 90s and read the reports of groups that were monitoring such things. I don't know as much about Europe. There are periodic surges that sometimes correlate with Israeli military action, but the idea that anti-Semitic violence is on the march doesn't seem borne out by the facts. Rather it seems to suit the purposes of defending the indefensible in Israel's treatment of the Palestinian majority living under its boot by whipping up peoples fears. It works on some, but I suspect even there it is getting tired. Anti-Semitism is real and needs to be fought. But the fight against it is not actually helped by misrepresenting rising anti-Zionist opinion as driven mainly by anti-Semitism when it is really driven Israeli actions.
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">
                For Change You Can REALLY Believe IN:
                <a href="http://www.thenation.com/doc/20081201/piven" rel="nofollow">
                 Obama needs a protest movement
                </a>
                <br/>
               </p>
               <p class="cb">
                by
                <a href="/user/uid:17404">
                 Christopher Day
                </a>
                on
                <a href="/comments/744905/29397364#c141">
                 Sat Jun 20, 2009 at 12:37:52 PM PDT
                </a>
               </p>
               <p class="cl">
                [
                <a href="#c56">
                 Parent

                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:98698">
                 heathlander
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:173827">
                 contessakitty
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               but your point is well taken. Hamas is embarassed by it and calls it a "historical document" that does not guide its present policies, though they haven't rescinded it officially for reasons having more to do with refusing to do what Israel demands than anything else. It lives on, however, reproduced endlessy on pro-Zionist websites.
              </p>
              <p>
               Its a case of the political use of instances of anti-Semitism for other purposes. A similar thing occurred in the NYC teachers strike against community control in Ocean Hill-Brownsville in 1968. Some small unsanctioned group handed out an anti-Semitic leaflet at a pro-community control rally. The teachers union got ahold of one of the few copies made and reproduced hundreds of thousands of copies of it to prove that the Black and Latino community organizations demanding community control were really anti-Semites. It was a stunt that did more to poison Black-Jewish relations in New York than the original leaflet makers could ever have hoped for.
              </p>
              <p>
               The fact that Hamas's politics have developed since the charter is inconveneient to the purposes of portraying them in a certain light and so the charter keeps getting dragged out. Its intellectually dishonest but what are you gonna do?
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               For Change You Can REALLY Believe IN:
               <a href="http://www.thenation.com/doc/20081201/piven" rel="nofollow">
                Obama needs a protest movement
               </a>
               <br/>
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:17404">
                Christopher Day
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/744905/29397529#c165">
                Sat Jun 20, 2009 at 12:48:51 PM PDT
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c75">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k29397529">

                blaming Hamas for not rescinding that portion of their charter, on the Israelis, is a flimsy excuse. It's simple enough: Hamas could simply rewrite their charter, dropping that piece of it. Nothing prevents them from rejecting that ugly bigotry. Nothing.
               </p>

                </span>

                 <dd>

               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 I'm not defending Hamas's failure to change their charter I'm just saying that it doesn't prove that it reflects their current outlook. Lots of groups are running around the world with un-rescinded founding documents that don't reflect the subsequent development in their thinking and this fixation on Hamas's stinky charter is intellectually dishonest.
                </p>
